3-ton lorry (Ford/Chevrolet).note: Primary transport for infantry and supplies

anti_tank_artillery.notes: Anti-tank guns at battalion level not included in divisional total

supply_logistics.fuel_supply: Dependent on British Eighth Army supply lines from Tobruk and coastal depots. Desert operations required extensive fuel for motorized transport. Division required approximately 12,000-15,000 gallons daily for normal operations.
supply_logistics.ammunition_supply: British .303 ammunition for rifles, 25-pdr artillery shells. Resupply from Eighth Army ordnance depots. Brigade dumps held 3-5 days of combat supplies. Critical shortage during Gazala battles (May-June 1942).
supply_logistics.water_supply: Critical constraint in desert operations. Water transported in jerrycans and water trucks. Minimum 1 gallon per man per day (drinking only), actual requirement 2-3 gallons (cooking, washing, vehicle cooling). Division daily need approximately 30,000-45,000 gallons.
supply_logistics.operational_radius: Approximately 150-200 miles from supply dumps with organic transport. Limited by fuel and water capacity. Resupply cycle 3-5 days typical for forward units.
supply_logistics.supply_status: As of June 1942, division was understrength and received composite units from 1st SA Division. Supply situation deteriorated during Gazala battles (May-June 1942) due to Axis interdiction of supply lines.

weather_environment.terrain_type: North African desert and coastal plain. Operations in Gazala Line and Tobruk areas. Rocky desert, sand, limited vegetation. Surface mix of hard-packed sand, gravel, rocks, occasional wadis (dry riverbeds).
weather_environment.temperature_range: Q1 1942 (Jan-Mar): Daytime 60-75°F (15-24°C), Night 40-50°F (4-10°C). Q2 1942 (Apr-Jun): Daytime 75-95°F (24-35°C), Night 55-70°F (13-21°C). Daily temperature swing 30-50°F.
weather_environment.seasonal_impacts: Winter (Q1): Occasional rain, cooler temperatures, better operating conditions for troops. Reduced water requirements. Spring/Summer (Q2): Increasing heat, sandstorms (khamsin winds), water scarcity becomes critical. Equipment overheating issues.
weather_environment.environmental_challenges: Desert navigation in featureless terrain. Dust and sand affecting engines and weapons, requiring frequent maintenance. Extreme temperature variations. Limited water sources - all water transported. Flies and disease vectors (dysentery). Scorpions and snakes. Desert sores and skin conditions.
weather_environment.weather_notes: June 1942 saw the division heavily engaged in Gazala battles during increasingly hot conditions (90-95°F daytime). Sandstorms reduced visibility. Water shortages exacerbated by combat tempo. Heat exhaustion significant casualty factor.

major_engagements.name: Gazala
major_engagements.outcome: Forced withdrawal after Axis breakthrough. Division fell back to Tobruk perimeter.

major_engagements.name: Tobruk garrison 1942
major_engagements.outcome: Division captured when Tobruk fell on June 21, 1942. Approximately 33,000 Allied troops captured. Division effectively ceased to exist as combat formation.

combat_history.combat_effectiveness: Division fought competently during Gazala battles but was undermanned and less experienced than 1st SA Division. The fall of Tobruk was more a failure of British higher command decisions than of the division's fighting quality. Division was understrength and receiving composite units (Blake Group) from 1st SA Division prior to Gazala.

validation.data_tier_rationale: Tier 2 (review_recommended, 68% complete): Source provides detailed unit organization but lacks specific strength figures for most sub-units. Equipment details inferred from standard British/Commonwealth TO&E. Source date (June 1942) is one quarter after requested period (Q1 1942).

gap_documentation.date_variance: Source document dated June 20, 1942 (Q2) used for Q1 1942 extraction. Assumed TO&E stability across quarters absent evidence of reorganization. This is one quarter later than requested.
gap_documentation.strength_estimates: Specific strength figures provided only for 1st SA Division in source (17,000 total, 5,000 non-Europeans). 2nd SA Division strengths estimated based on similar unit types, standard Commonwealth battalion sizes (~750 men), and note that 2nd SA Div was understrength.
gap_documentation.equipment_details: Equipment types inferred from standard British Commonwealth infantry division TO&E for 1942 period. Specific serial numbers and exact quantities not available in source. Vehicle counts estimated based on divisional transport requirements.
gap_documentation.command_personnel: Commander and staff names not provided in source document. Ranks and positions inferred from standard British Commonwealth division structure.

validation.source_bibliography: Agar-Hamilton, J, & Turner, L.C., Crisis in the Desert, May-July 1942, Oxford University Press, 1952

notes: Source document is dated June 20, 1942 (1942-Q2), one quarter later than requested 1942-Q1. TO&E assumed stable from Q1 to Q2 1942 unless major reorganization occurred.
Beer Group (composite battalion ex 1st SA Infantry Division) was under command of 11th Indian Brigade, not 2nd SA Division.
2nd SA Field Battery was under command of 25th Field Regiment, RA (British), not divisional control.
20th Field Park Company, SA Engineer Corps, was under command of C.R.E. 88th Sub-Area, not divisional control.
Division included both European and non-European (African) personnel. Based on 1st SA Division ratio (5,000 of 17,000), estimated ~4,000 non-Europeans in 2nd SA Division.
Blake Group was a composite battalion formed from elements of 1st SA Division, indicating 2nd SA Division was understrength.
Die Middellandse Regiment had 'B' Company detached to 1st SA Division.
Division was largely destroyed when Tobruk fell on June 21, 1942, just one day after the source document date. This TO&E represents the division's last complete organization before its destruction.
